Background and Analysis:
	 
A proposed revision to the district's mission statement (board policy 1200) was presented for first reading at the June 15, 2015, Board of Trustees meeting. The policy has been revised to incorporate language required by community college baccalaureate degree pilot program legislation and to ensure compliance with accreditation standards. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is indicated by strikethrough. This is a technical revision only. A full review of the district's mission statement will take place in 2016 as part of the development of a new district strategic plan.
	 
The revised policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on May 22, 2015.
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 66010.4(a)(3) and 78042(b)
Accreditation Standard I.A.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Interim Chancellor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
A proposed new board policy concerning institutional effectiveness was presented for first reading at the June 15, 2015, Board of Trustees meeting. The policy and a related new administrative procedure were developed in response to provisions of the Seymour-Campbell Student Success Act of 2012 that tie funding to the development of a goals framework that addresses accreditation status, fiscal viability, student performance and outcomes, and programmatic compliance with state and federal guidelines as well as the Senate Bill 876 requirement that the goals be challenging and quantifiable, address achievement gaps for underrepresented populations, and align the educational attainment of California's adult population to the workforce and economic needs of the state.
	 
The proposed policy was approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee and the Chancellor's Advisory Council on May 22, 2015.
	 
References:
Accreditation standards I.B.5-9
Education Code Sections 78210 et seq. and 84754.6
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Interim Chancellor
Additional contact names:

Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Cupertino Mayor Rod Sinks will join trustees to discuss Santa Clara County transportation concerns along the Highway 85 corridor.
	 
The possibility of working with the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority to develop a combined transit center and parking project was discussed at the October 6, 2014, and February 9, 2015, Board of Trustees meetings. At the February 9 meeting, trustees approved the hiring of consulting firm Brailsford and Dunlavey, Inc. to conduct a feasibility study to analyze the transit center proposal along with other mixed use land development options. 
	 
As part of the feasibility study research, James Birkey of Brailsford and Dunlavey, Inc. and Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy met with the City of Cupertino's Mayor, City Manager, and Director of Public Works to garner input regarding various development options, including the possible transit center. Vice Chancellor McElroy, President Cheng, and trustee Swenson also attended the June 2, 2015, special meeting of the Cupertino City Council, which included a study session item regarding a potential transportation tax measure for Santa Clara County, to gain a broader perspective of regional transportation issues. Trustee Swenson provided a synopsis of the Council's study session at the June 15, 2015, Board meeting, and the governing board asked that Mayor Sinks be invited to the July meeting to further explore the issue. 
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Interim Chancellor
Additional contact names:

Yes (Attached presentation posted 7/13/15 at 4:15 p.m.)

Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 15, 2015, the Board of Trustees adopted a Resolution of Notice of Intention to grant easements to Pacific Gas and Electric Company for electrical and natural gas service at the Education Center in Sunnyvale, California.  In accordance with Education Code Section 81312, a notice of adoption of the Resolution was publicly advertised and posted in three locations in the district.
	 
The notice was published in the San Jose Post Record on July 6, 2015.  Copies of the notice were posted at the Education Center site, the district Business Services office at Foothill College, and in the Administration Building at De Anza College.
	 
At this meeting of the Board of Trustees on July 13, 2015, a public hearing upon the question of granting the easements will be held as required by Education Code Section 81313.
	 
Unless a petition protesting against granting the proposed easements, signed by at least ten percent of the qualified electors of the district, is filed at this public hearing, the Board may adopt a resolution authorizing its Secretary to execute a deed granting the easements.  The resolution must be passed by at least two-thirds of the board members.

Vendor:  DL Falk Construction

Amount:  $77,368
For:
Prime Contract Change Order #07 - revises the original contract sum between the District and D.L. Falk Construction to improve facility performance and maintainability.   
	 
040 COR# 35 Removal of electrical at Wireless Access Points (WAPs) – due to technology changes, electrical is no longer required to be installed at WAP locations. This change request omitted the electrical at these locations. (OD) 
050 COR# 46 CCD#17 electrical, telecom & Audio-Visual changes were driven by new electrified furniture requirements & new technology changes.  These changes are being made to improve the facility performance. (OD)
053 COR #49 RFI #155 Add exterior railings at 3 locations at the NW side of patio in order to detour students from walking over curbs and into landscaped areas. (OD)
054 COR 53 RFI #194 Lower wire mold at various locations to accommodate new furniture. (OD)
055 COR 51 Changes in signage wording and fonts at library and reference desks to be in alignment with new references being used. (OD)
056 COR 52 RFI #187 Ceiling Height Revisions – Existing ceiling height was 7’-10” instead of 8’-0” as required in rooms 107, 108, 130 & 134.  Ductwork needed to be modified, drywall finishes extended up 2” sprinkler heads raised and relocated, trim added and plywood framing installed. (FC)
057 COR #54 CCD #19 Change to WAP Wire Mold & Boxes – With the elimination of the electrical at the WAPs, the size of wire mold and boxes were changed to a smaller piece. (OD)
058 COR #55 CCD#20 2nd Floor Electrical Changes to Accommodate Furniture – additional power was required at 4 locations to accommodate new electrified tables. (OD)
059 COR #50 RFI #161 Existing concrete wall at rooms 209 & 215 did not have penetrations to accommodate the duct that needed to feed into them.  The wall required to be scanned and cored for duct installation. (ADD)
060 COR #56 RFI #186 Vent Pipe in Room 211.  Existing vent pipe was in a wall in the elevator machine room.  Once the wall was gone the pipe is about 6' out in room 211 running from the restrooms on the 1st floor ceiling up to the roof.  Pipe was re-routed.

Background and Analysis:
	 
This is a modified rebid of Project 162, Parking and Circulation Phase 3 that consists of constructing a new staircase from the loop road traffic signal near Lot 1 to Lot 1A behind the Smithwick Theater. The work will replace the existing staircase that is in poor condition to a new code-compliant staircase.  The staircase will be similar to stairs built near parking lots 2 and 3. A deductive alternate to simplify the staircase construction is being accepted in order to reduce the project cost.

Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will require the contractor to complete interior improvements in a new ETS training room (formerly the Board Room in the District Office Building) so that ETS can conduct staff training classes, large group meetings, and other functions in the newly-renovated ETS building.  The scope of work will include interior wall framing, finishes, painting, carpeting and electrical, mechanical, and telecommunication upgrades.  Alternate #1 includes the removal of six modular buildings that will be vacated by ETS when it completes move-in activities this summer.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 17 and April 24, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 26, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:

The apparent low bidder is E. R. Brothers Company, Inc. (E. R. Brothers). E. R. Brothers Company, Inc .has confirmed that its base bid proposal amount of $295,000 and Alternate #1 amount of $19,000 is true and accurate for the work as specified. 
	 
However, the District received a bid protest from the second lowest responsive, responsible bidder R. C. Benson & Sons, Inc. on June 13, 2015 alleging that E. R. Brothers does not meet the criteria of a responsive bidder in that it had an unfair economic advantage over other bidders by not listing subcontractors for the project.  E. R. Brothers holds California Contractors Licenses A, B, C-16, and C-16.  Approximately 18% of the work required on the project is mechanical work related to the HVAC system.  District staff investigated the intentions of E. R. Brothers’ methodology and performance of the mechanical scope of work and consulted with its legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret of Jaret & Jaret Attorneys at Law, Mr. Michael Vlamming of Scarth Lyons & Associates, and also the California Department of Industrial Relations – Public Works Department.  District staff and its legal counsel concluded that the methodology described by E. R. Brothers satisfies the legal requirements to self-perform the work and recommend that the protest (see attached) be denied and the contract be awarded to E. R. Brothers.  
	 
In 2013, E. R. Brothers completed the Foothill College Art Room Lighting & Multimedia and Minor Site Improvements projects.  They have also completed projects for the cities of San Mateo and Menlo Park.  The project will be paid for with Measure C funds.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At its May 4, 2015, meeting, the Board of Trustees authorized the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1728-141 – Campus Center and Bridge Painting and Staining at Foothill College in the amount of $135,000 to Industrial Coating & Restoration Services, Inc.
	 
District staff sent a Notice of Award letter on May 5, 2015 to Industrial Coating & Restoration Services, Inc. (Industrial Coating) requesting Certificates of General, Liability and Workers Compensation Insurance coverage; Performance Bonds; Labor and Materials Bonds; and the executed Contract Agreement for the scope of work by May 12, 2015.  Industrial Coating was unable to provide all such required documents by that date. Specifically the workers compensation insurance coverage, the bonds, and the agreement were not received in a timely manner; the Contract Agreement was received on May 21, 2015, and on June 24, 2015, the District received the Performance and Labor and Material bonds.
	 
Furthermore, on May 27, 2015, the California Contractors State License Board (CSLB) “suspended” Industrial Coating’s contractor’s license # 880502 for “failure to comply with Workers Comp.”  Only once the Workers Compensation certificate or exemption statement is received and processed by the CSLB, will the suspension be lifted.
	 
As of this writing, Industrial Coating’s contractor’s license is still suspended, and the District cannot enter into a contract with a Contractor whose license is not current and active with the CSLB. 
	 
District staff, in consultation with its legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret of Jaret & Jaret Attorneys at Law, have been regularly communicating with Industrial Coating regarding each of the outstanding issues since May 5, 2015.  Since Industrial Coating has not yet been able to successfully lift its licensure suspension with the CSLB, it is our recommendation that the District’s Board of Trustees exercise its right to rescind authorization to award the contract to Industrial Coating.
	 
The second lowest responsive, responsible bidder is OnPoint Construction (OnPoint).  District staff met with representatives of OnPoint on June 29, 2015, and it has confirmed that its bid proposal pricing as submitted is still valid. OnPoint is willing to perform the work as indicated, however it cannot be completed in the same time frame as if the contract were awarded on May 4th.  OnPoint has completed similar work for other public agencies such as San Francisco Unified School District, City of Fremont, and Peralta Community College District.
